title: The prevalence of abrahamic religions (Christianity, Islam, etc) is not evidence for their validity, and is explained by many other factors.

author: peleles
text:
Christianity/Islam have been prevalent for a mere 1400-1600 years, which is not impressive considering how long modern humans have been around. I get that people suffer from a "since it's like this today, it was like this in the past and will be like this forever" syndrome, but that's just not reality. .

Worldwide spread happened during Christianity's colonial era, and was limited to places that were already weak, or weakened thanks to massive mortality caused by diseases Europeans brought with them. China, India, Japan were never converted. South Korea was (it's now 1/3 Christian) but they seem to be moving toward the type of irreligion that characterizes other first world nations.

I guess I've never understood this way of thinking :/

author: peleles
text:
I've heard plenty of people make that argument, though. Christianity's growth is often used to prove its special status and Muslims make similar claims.

I think the atheist version of it makes more sense, in that if there were a god which made itself known to everyone, leaving free will intact (think Jesus in Judea) then the only thing that would matter is what an individual chose to do with that fact. Since the existence of the god would be a given, there'd be no need to resort to counting conversions and conquests as "evidence" of anything.

author: peleles
text:
> Then you ought to be able to find a blog or article online that makes the argument popularity alone makes Christianity true.

Really, it's very common to look at numbers as proof that some belief or another is true. You do it yourself, in the same post:

>...the next come back of an atheist is to say there is no evidence at all so 90% of the world is open to a God or higher power for no reason at all - Which is an extraordinary claim that requires some evidence itself.

Anyhoo, yes, as you point out the religious def outnumber the non-religious. For me, that says nothing about the truth/falsity of belief.

Note the 90% don't all worship the same god. There isn't agreement even within religions on the nature and demands of their god, as there isn't evidence for any of these belief systems.

This poses a problem only if you believe that there's one god who will punish people for failing to worship it, cuz you'd expect that entity, more than any of the others, to make its presence clear, giving people a real choice. One such god did it--think Jesus, miracling his way thru Judea.
